Modification_Detail.description: Updated schema version. Adding missing "investigation" references.

Changed inst LIDs from u:n:p:c:i:instID.scID to u:n:p:c:i:scID.instID Changed LIDs from urn:nasa:pds: to urn:esa:psa: And per "Guide toPDS4 Context Products" v1.7, changed all lidvid_reference to lid_reference

Instrument.name: Radio Science Subsystem for VEX
Instrument.description:
The Venus Express (VEX) mission utilized a comprehensive radio science investigation involving both spacecraft and ground-based instrumentation. The European Space Agency's (ESA) facilities in Australia and Spain, along with NASA's Deep Space Network (DSN), supported these operations. The spacecraft communicated using S-band and X-band frequencies, employing various antenna configurations for data collection.
The VEX mission focused on two primary types of radio science measurements: radiometric measurements, which included range and Doppler data to infer gravity fields and spacecraft trajectory, and radio propagation measurements, which analyzed how signals interacted with Venus's atmosphere and surface to gather insights on atmospheric conditions and surface properties.
In particular, gravity measurements helped to map the planet's mass distribution and internal structure by utilizing data from previous missions, while radio occultation techniques enhanced the understanding of the atmosphere's temperature, pressure, and electron density. Additionally, bistatic radar experiments were aimed at understanding the surface material's properties.
Operational constraints affected observations, especially during critical periods where different instruments contended for data collection opportunities. Over time, technical issues reduced the effectiveness of certain radio transmissions, leading to modifications in study focus. The calibration processes were undertaken to ensure the reliability of collected data, with the performance of the ground systems being crucial to the success of these investigations.
Key personnel included experts from various institutions, emphasizing interdisciplinary collaboration in the execution of these scientific objectives.
Overall, the VEX mission's radio science endeavors provided significant contributions to our understanding of Venus's atmospheric dynamics, gravity field, and surface characteristics.
